choices.D: Create a separate VLAN for the DSL connection
choices.A: Add the DSL connection to the neighbor table for OSPF protocol
choices.B: Change the routing protocol to EIGRP for the fiber connection
choices.C: Increase the administrative distance of the DSL connection

questions.question_text: A network administrator is configuring a static DSL connection on the perimeter router to use a backup route to the fiber connection using OSPF routing. The administrator notices all traffic is going over the DSL connection and both links are working. Which of the following should the administrator do to adjust the routing settings for the fiber connection to be used by the router?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Since the DSL connection was configured as Static it would be given an AD of 1. The OSPF fiber connection would have automatically been assigned an AD of 110 being OSPF. So yes you would have to increase the AD distance of the static DSL route in order for the best path to be the fiber OSPF.

Selected Answer: C
Administrative distance is a metric used by routers to determine the preference of a route. The lower the administrative distance, the higher the preference. By increasing the administrative distance of the DSL connection, the router will prefer the fiber connection since it has a lower administrative distance.

Selected Answer: C
C:Increase the administrative distance of the DSL connection

Selected Answer: A
A. Answer C just doesn't make sense.

comments.content:
I think it's just a bad question I can't wrap my head around. 

1. DSL says static connection but doesn't really say a static route specifically. I guess this is where Im getting confused.
2. Fiber is using OSPF routing.
3. If DSL is setup OSPF then network will choose the best path to take with less network traffic. Since it's a backup route, I would want the same routing protocol and let the network decide.
4. I guess if DSL is a static route then yes it'll take that route.

Both links are working so no issue with AD. Admin wants a backup, fiber is using ospf, DSL needs to be added to OSPF neighbor? Right?

OSPF auto chooses best path to take, but if DSL is not an OSPF neighbor how will it know to take fiber path? IDK..

questions.question_text: A Chief Information Officer wants to monitor network breaching in a passive, controlled manner. Which of the following would be BEST to implement?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A honeypot is a computer system that is intentionally exposed to attack in order to gather information about attackers. Honeypots are often used to monitor network breaches in a passive, controlled manner.
IPS is not passive Minx... Honeypot is passive. The answer it definitely A!! You can even go onto ChatGPT and Google Bard for reassurance.

Selected Answer: A
Definitely not C because it states PASSIVE manner (which could be done by an IDS (Intruder Detection System). IPS are used to react on breaches. So correct here is the honeypot to regards how intruders try to breach a system or a network.

comments.content: You're thinking of IDS probably. An IPS takes an active in stopping an attack

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
KEY WORD IS PASSIVE
There's nothing passive about prevention. If someone is trying to get in and get's outright stopped... they're gonna know something happened.

Selected Answer: C
802.1Q is a trunking protocol

comments.content: The Q has a little trunk.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
it is C because without or with a faulty 802.1q config (trunking protocol) the switch will not pass on the message to due vlan.
its not a because there is only one switch

Selected Answer: C
Trunked ports are used to carry traffic for multiple VLANs over a single physical link. The fact that frames are not being forwarded on a trunked port indicates a problem with the 802.1Q configuration.
STP issues typically result in intermittent connectivity or complete loss of connectivity rather than preventing frames from being forwarded.

Selected Answer: A
ChatGPT: STP (Spanning Tree Protocol) is a network protocol used to prevent loops in Ethernet networks. It ensures a loop-free topology by selectively blocking redundant links. One of the main functions of STP is to prevent broadcast storms and network instability that can occur due to loops.

questions.question_text: A technician monitors a switch interface and notices it is not forwarding frames on a trunked port. However, the cable and interfaces are in working order. Which of the following is MOST likely the cause of the issue?

comments.content: Welcome to CompTIA testing... half the questions don't make sense and the other half is missing information and then all of them fall under a 'non-reality' scenario that you would never actually fall into.
Hope you made it my dude, the day before big tests is rough

discussion.content:
This question makes no bloody sense.

A. Implementing WPA2 - this clearly wont make a difference to being able to "see" the SSIDs
B. Omnidirectional antennas - they're already had a site survery and the question specifically says that the signal strength is fine everywhere for both APs
C. Highest power setting - see above
D. Using 802.11ac - devices only supporting 2.4ghz won't be able to see the SSID

Why do they even have separate APs and SSIDs for the 802.11b and 802.11a networks?? Why don't they do the sensible thing and upgrade to a 802.11ax network??
Why am I wasting my time on this question instead of just moving on and praying I don't get it in my exam tomorrow??!!

comments.content: 802.11ac is not backwards compatible with the 2.4GHz range, only the 5GHz range.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
“A site survey was recently commissioned, and the results verified acceptable RSSI from both APs in all user areas.“ a site survey would show the deficit in RSSI which the scenario clearly states is NOT the issue. 802.11a operates at 5GHz and 802.11b operates @ 2.4 GHz. 802.11ac is backwards compatible with both 5 and 2.4 GHz and can auto negotiate with Wi-Fi device that use these standards.

It's understandable to find the question confusing. In real-world scenarios, network issues can often be complex and multifaceted, so it might not always be immediately clear which solution addresses the problem best.

The question aims to test understanding of various aspects of wireless networking and the impacts of different settings. However, if the site survey shows acceptable RSSI and the SSIDs are broadcasted, the problem might not be straightforward, and multiple factors could be at play.

The solutions provided in the question each address different aspects:

A. WPA2 Enterprise addresses authentication and compatibility.
B. Omnidirectional Antennas addresses potential coverage issues.
C. Power Settings addresses signal strength and potential interference.
D. 802.11ac addresses performance and capacity.

Selected Answer: D
among all D seems to make sense since AC is MU-MIMO that will help.

Selected Answer: D
It's D for sure.

Selected Answer: D
D for sure.

Here we go again. Before i read the question saw 4 problems with the image. But the question says that the RSSI is good is all users area. (this is assuming of course that they mean someone checked multiple spots and confirmed strength is good and not just check the system settings for the AP because then the answer B comes back into play) that means you the power level and direction is good. 

Now I'm stuck between A and D because of the stuff not said. Was there a MDM Mobile Device Manager installed on the phones not allowing them to connect to a WPA2-psk. Are they implying that 802.11ac allows 2.4 ghz at 802.11n. 

Someone said the answer was changed to 802.11AX. In general they should be required to change it to that even though it doesn't really solve the problem. I'm going to answer D not cause its the right answer. Just it's inhumane to expect people to work at 11Mbps.

comments.content: nope sorry, 802.11ac is only backward compatible with 802.11a, the only other pre-existing 5GHz freq wifi Generation.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Configuring both APs to use the 802.11ac wireless standard: 802.11ac is backward compatible with 802.11n, and most modern devices support it. It operates on both 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz bands, which would likely solve the visibility issue for most modern devices.

Selected Answer: B
I don't believe changing the encryption to WPA2 will increase visibility for the devices.
You could make an argument that increased power might help, but I would imagine this would be more meaningful if one was set to high and the other set to low
Configuring both APs to use 802.11ac likely is incorrect because it is only backwards compatible N at 5GHz, not the 2.4GHz band.
By making both AP's omnidirectional, it appears that the scope of the AP will increase for all users.

The correct answer is D. Configuring both APs to use the 802.11ac wireless standard.

The 802.11ac standard is a more recent wireless standard that offers higher throughput and better range than older standards1. If some devices are not seeing both corporate SSIDs, it could be because those devices are not compatible with the wireless standard currently used by the APs1. By configuring both APs to use the 802.11ac standard, which is widely supported by modern devices, it would increase the likelihood of all user devices being able to see both corporate SSIDs1.
In the actual exam there's an AX answer option which makes sense

Selected Answer: D
I would go for D. Configuring both APs to use the 802.11ac wireless standard.
Another bad question but I would go for D. I think what they are getting at is that not all client devices work on 5Ghz network. As the Wi-Fi survey has ruled out its not an RSSI or power levels it is not about antennas etc. I believe they want you to select a wireless standard that covers both 2.4 and 5ghz so all devices can connect. I know that there is confusion around 802.11ac, however it does does work with 2.4GHz devices. look it up!

comments.content: But it is a more modern standard, so mobile devices may be more likely to connect to it

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
This is the answer.

Based on the given information, the most appropriate change to ensure that all user devices can see both corporate SSIDs would be:

B. Implementing omnidirectional antennas for both APs

Explanation:
The issue here is that some users are unable to see both corporate SSIDs on their mobile devices. This indicates that the problem lies with the coverage or signal propagation of the access points (APs). The fact that the site survey verified acceptable RSSI (Received Signal Strength Indication) suggests that the power settings of the APs are likely sufficient.

comments.content:
Incorrect:
Question clearly states, "A site survey was recently commissioned, and the results verified acceptable RSSI from both APs in all user areas" which discounts coverage. The second part of your explanation contradicts the first.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
as madperk said

Selected Answer: B
B. Implementing omnidirectional antennas for both APs

Selected Answer: B
I think switching both to omnidirectional is the most logical answer. Only some users are reporting this issue, they could be outside (behind) the directional antenna.

comments.content: i agree with you on that one. Since the AP2 is directional you will only recieve the strong singal out of one direction.

choices.B: Implementing omnidirectional antennas for both APs
choices.D: Configuring both APs to use the 802.11ac wireless standard
choices.A: Implementing the WPA2 Enterprise authentication standard
choices.C: Configuring the highest power settings for both APs

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. Single-mode

Single-mode fiber optic cables can transmit data over much longer distances compared to multimode fiber. They are designed for long-haul connections and are suitable for intercontinental networking. Single-mode fiber is capable of carrying higher bandwidths over extended distances, making it a common choice for wide-area networks (WANs) and long-distance connections.
A and D won't work because they're copper cables and those aren't going to reach across continents. Single vs Multi-mode fiber are the other two and Single mode is for longer distances.

questions.question_text: An infrastructure company is implementing a cabling solution to connect sites on multiple continents. Which of the following cable types should the company use for this project?
